clinical_study.brief_title: Light Flashes to Treat Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD)
clinical_study.official_title: Treating Sleep Disruption in Teens With Millisecond Light Exposure During Sleep

collaborator.agency: VA Palo Alto Health Care System

clinical_study.source: VA Palo Alto Health Care System

brief_summary.textblock: Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD) is a sleep disruption that commonly occurs in teens and manifests as a difficulty in waking up in the morning, going to sleep early enough at night, and daytime disturbances such as depression, fatigue, and restlessness. The purpose of this study is to determine if brief flashes of light, that are scheduled to occur during sleep, are effective in treating DSPD.

primary_outcome.description: Determined by questionnaire (Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: at the begining and end of intervention (4 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale for Children (depressive symptoms) SNAP-IV 26 (ADHD symptoms)

arm_group.description: three hours of a sequence of light flashes (4000 lux, 3 msec, every 30 seconds); occurs during three hours immediately prior to desired waketime
during three hours immediately prior to desired waketime, subjects will receive no light (light flash device will be disabled)

intervention.description: three hours of a sequence of light flashes (4000 lux, 3 msec, every 30 seconds); occurs during three hours immediately prior to desired waketime

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female
- Full-time in high school
- primary sleep complaint consistent with delayed sleep phase disorder
Exclusion Criteria:
- sleep only in prone position
- currently taking medications specifically for the treatment of a sleep disorder

reference.citation: Zeitzer JM, Ruby NF, Fisicaro RA, Heller HC. Response of the human circadian system to millisecond flashes of light. PLoS One. 2011;6(7):e22078. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0022078. Epub 2011 Jul 8.
